Questions.QuestionText:
The goal of this questionnaire is to help you assess the Operational Readiness maturity of your service and to help you understand what might be the appropriate next steps for you on your Operational Readiness journey.

These questions are intended to be completed for one team (typically reporting to the same line manager and usually consisting of between 5 and 15 people).
Prioritise SLO/SLA appropriately. Helps identify how much effort to allocate for reliability of each service. Important for microservices for teams to reliably build dependencies on your service.
Does the service have Service Level Agreements (either external or an internal commitment) e.g. contractual?

SLIs (Service Level Indicators). Measurable: Taken from monitoring. Actionable alerts if service degrades. Short timeframes, for example hourly e.g.
  • Request Latency – 99% of requests per hour on a system are served within 300ms.
  • Failures per total number of requests – 99% of requests per hour are successfully completed
Does the team have SLIs (Service Level Indicators)?

Answers.Answer: Yes, taken from monitoring, and there are actionable alerts if the service degrades

Questions.QuestionText:
SLOs (Service Level Objectives), with consequences, give common incentives across team(s). Early warning before SLAs exceeded. Realistic reliability goals.

Longer timeframe than SLI’s.

Define your Error Budgets & Error Budget Policy (consequences)
  • Must be set at the appropriate levels
  • Too high and costs can rise rapidly
  • Smaller error budget which can impede change
  • Too low and your customers will be unhappy
Are there Service Level Objectives with consequences?

Answers.Answer: Yes, and the consequences are effective
Yes, but the consequences are not always effective

Questions.QuestionText: Do Site Reliability Engineers / key Operations staff have the ability (skills) to make tomorrow better than today (tick all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Contribution to application and infrastructure architecture

Questions.QuestionText: Do Operations / Site Reliability Engineers have the ability to regulate workload e.g. TOIL (Manual, Repetitive, Automatable, reactive, Lacks enduring value)?

Answers.Answer: Yes, TOIL bounded to <50% of Operations for Site Reliability Engineers / Key Operations staff

Questions.QuestionText: Is a shared responsibility model successfully used to handover systems to Site Reliability Engineers / Operations?

Answers.Answer: Yes, we ensure a Operational Readiness Review is completed and the Platform is safe to operate before handover

Questions.QuestionText: Disaster Recovery plan is documented, and date of last and next DR Test noted?

Answers.Answer: Yes including RTO (recovery time objective) and RPO (recovery point objective)

Questions.QuestionText: Highly Available & Redundant
Are dependencies identified and visualised? e.g. Third-party systems, monitoring, networking

Location / region or individual service within each / Components. e.g. consider Application Architecture and running across multiple AZs/Regions.

Automated resolution in place for all in-scope failure scenarios including the following where relevant?:

  • Machine dies, rack fails, or cluster goes offline
  • Network fails between two Data Centres
  • For each type of server that talks to other servers (its backends):
    • How to detect when backends die, and what to do when they die
    • How to terminate or restart without affecting clients or users
    • Load balancing, rate-limiting, timeout, retry and error handling behaviour
Able to handle spike of traffic? For each component, traffic volume, launch spikes.

Answers.Answer: Yes e.g. using relevant mitigation such as Sizing, Auto-scaling, Containers, serverless architecture etc

Questions.QuestionText: How will we know when we need more capacity?

Answers.Answer: Alert or automated increase safely in advance with regular Load Testing identifying capacity requirements before Production (daily/weekly)

Questions.QuestionText: How quickly can we add more capacity?

Answers.Answer: All key dependencies automate increase on approach to capacity
Manual changes required, always completed before impact
On occasion, capacity limits are hit before being extended

Questions.QuestionText: Avoid Single Points of Failure (SPOF) for key dependencies that could cause SLAs / SLOs to be breached. Does your system withstand component failures? (tick all that apply)

Answers.Answer: Services are running in clusters scaled across locations/AZs/Regions with data replication (where applicable)
When a component's dependencies are unhealthy, the component itself does not report as unhealthy. It can continue to serve requests in a degraded manner.
Service dependencies: Graceful degradation, avoid accidentally overrunning third-party services
Service dependencies: Playing nice with syndicated partners, mail systems, services
Service dependencies: Queuing systems, streaming systems, workflows, and load balancers are loosely coupled.

Questions.QuestionText: On-boarding new developers
Do you effectively ensure staff reacting to incidents are skilled to troubleshoot all the tech stack? (tick all that apply)

Answers.Answer: Standardise on libraries, languages for easier developer onboarding and Production troubleshooting
Look for opportunities to implement good design patterns
Know your licenses - Open Source Permissive (MIT/Apache) vs Copy Left (GNU/MPL) etc

Questions.QuestionText: Security Best Practice Review
Is Security always a top priority? e.g. all of the following as a minimum? (tick all that apply)

Answers.Answer: Ensure no credentials stored in app
Code defensively for OWASP e.g. SQL injections, XSS attacks etc

Questions.QuestionText: Meeting industry best practice regarding security of application and platform?

Answers.Answer: Unsure or not demonstrated regulations are complied with

Questions.QuestionText: Penetration Testing passed (if required)?
Secret / Key Management reviewed as effective and compliant?
System Administrator Authentication reviewed and auditable as effective and compliant?

Continuous Improvement: Obtain Peer Review / Fresh eyes. Kaizen (small, ongoing positive improvements of working practices). Consider rotating developers off projects every few months to gain fresh eyes on projects. Easier when pushing small batches.
Continuous Improvement for the above?
Run Load Tests & Understand Limits
Before a service goes live, you know where your breaking points are?
You know the bare minimum number of instances needed to run your average throughput?
You Know maximum throughput you can handle with current architecture?
You calculate throughput per instance ratio (scale unit) so you can accurately setup proper auto-scaling in a cost optimised way?
Documentation for your App and Platform
Stored your documentation close to your code e.g. Readme in code and links to wiki / alternative including how to install, troubleshoot?
What does the code do?
How to install & run it?
Documentation - Standard Operating Procedures
How to interact with it (stop, start, restart)?
How to configure it?
How to troubleshoot it?

Answers.Answer: Application Run Books - Set actions (documentation and automated solutions for resolving issues)
Application Run Books - particularly for out of hours scenarios.

Questions.QuestionText: Metrics and Dashboards are available?
Monitoring - Insight
Visualisations - how do you know what's going on. Dashboards show the right things that may go wrong?
Dashboard health - viable dashboard? (false positives low)
Ensure Developers are, for Prod & Non-Production environments with same tools (tick all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Early insight into what is coming to Prod
Close Feedback loops: Site Reliability engineers / lead Operations staff able to let Devs see how their software operates (ceremonies / information radiators)

Questions.QuestionText: Monitoring - Customer
Analytics / Read User Monitoring (RUM): Customer focused monitoring?  Understand how customers use software / where they fall out of process / where they get frustrated

Answers.Answer: Using percentiles to expose where users are experiencing issues (averages hide issues) e.g. have alarms for: 99, 90, 75, vs steady state e.g. mean, median as relevant?
Close Feedback loops: Site Reliability engineers / lead Operations staff able to let Devs see how their software operates (ceremonies / information radiators)
Real User Monitoring (RUM) active - e.g. javascript in browser reporting real user experience e.g. includes page load times, DNS issues, traffic bottlenecks etc

Questions.QuestionText: Monitoring - Code
STM (Synthetic Transaction Monitoring) / APM (Application Performance Monitoring) / Log Analytics (tick all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Synthetic Monitoring - Automated testing to measure performance?
Visibility into how app is performing internally e.g. how long are certain relevant calls to resources taking?
Metrics trending up or down visible and alerted where relevant?
The tools indicate what part of the app is generating the highest number of errors?

Questions.QuestionText: Effective error and performance logging (instrumentation) is built into the application, noting needs above?
Continuously improve: Learn from system under inspection - Each system should have a 'heartbeat' that appears off when unhealthy?
Database: DBA monitoring proactive in identifying issues before they become impacting incidents?
Configuration 'Drift Management' in place?
Effective Service and Infrastructure monitoring in place?
Monitoring - Security
Monitoring effective for Auditing and Compliance for effective Governance, including Threat Detection?
Monitoring - Team / access
Teams access to each of the above (tick all that apply)?
Logging
Consistent Log Format? Consider JSON
Log levels: User Log Levels correctly [INFO/WARN/CRIT] inc UTC & microseconds?
Add context for your logging? e.g. transaction / correlation ids

Logging of behaviours? For pattern analysis such as destinations, frequency/periodicity of identified risk incidents, and/or volumes exchanged, which indicate whether the behaviour exceeds a specified baseline
Application (and other sources of logs) are periodically reviewed to consider how analytics will be used on this data?
Alerting
Can you have someone else manage hosting your alerting? Non-core, leverage 3rd party managed service if possible
Alerts adjusted to appropriate level for application/platform? e.g. IF can auto-recover e.g. VM restarting, then do not alert (but do notify for later review)
Auto-scaling alert avoidance - avoiding alerts from high CPU/Memory if auto-scaling (where by design)?
Alerts calibrated correctly e.g. Verify if needs to be fixed now and is Actionable? Avoiding getting people out of bed unless required
Tickets created for relevant alerts? - Implemented auto-ticket creation where relevant - including non-urgent actions?
Build Proper Escalation Paths For Alerts? e.g. tools with built in capability (PagerDuty etc), Primary => Secondary => Team => Management
P1 paging escalations e.g. P1 Auto escalate where not Acknowledged?
Review alerts/acknowledgements - Review alerts periodically that have been acknowledged or silenced beyond a tolerable threshold?
Alerting in place for:
Team(s) responsible for each of the above clearly identified and responsible?

Adopted Automated Testing early? e.g. Test Driven Development (TDD): Build a Test first, fails. Develop code to is passes. Refactor/optimise code. Repeat.
  • Builds confidence in code released
  • Allowed more testing of app in less time
  • Manual testing can become error prone
Can you confirm the level of test/code coverage? e.g. how much of solution been tested?
Have you automated common testing tasks & integrated into build process?
Integrated UI tests automated?
Can you confirm how many critical or high-priority bugs are still open? (Watch out for the 're-prioritising bug severity downwards' trick in order to meet the quality goals!)?
Artifact repository tool in use?
Automated application deployment (consider how fast to deploy, and roll back)?
Outage required for changes?
Platform Deployment tools / process confirmed?
Automated database deployment?
Understand what changes to the database are needed to support new code releases (check all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Avoid removing columns/changing type of columns, only made additions to reduce risk
Test migrations against test copies of database
Keep revision history of database migrations for reference

Questions.QuestionText: Speed up and reduce risk for deployments / experiments (check all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Canary Pools e.g. direct % of traffic to new version of app, then increase % gradually
Blue/Green deployments (switch from one to the other)

Questions.QuestionText: Able to use Dark Deploys & Feature Flags (check all that apply)?

Answers.Answer: Opt In - Test new features with selected users?
Kill Switch - Disable poorly performing features?
Scalable Roll Outs - Do % roll outs of new features?
Block Users - Prevent selected users from features?

Questions.QuestionText: Test and compare new features / Continuous usability and user experience testing?

Answers.Answer: Sunset Old Features - Safely decommission old features?
